facts.text: Suit for partition filed by plaintiffs.
Dispute over shop-room at the northwest corner of plot No. 1238 claimed by plaintiffs but disallowed by High Court.

Dispute over three items in Schedule C to the plaint (items 1 to 3), covered by four usufructuary mortgages Ex-B-1 to B-4, claimed by first defendant (first respondent) as exclusively belonging to him.
Trial Court accepted first defendant's case on exclusive ownership of items 1-3 in Schedule C and partially upheld possession of shop-room.

Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 77 of 1958, judgment dated January 31, 1963, affirmed Trial Court's findings on items 1-3 and held shop-room allotted to defendant No. 1 in 1938 partition.

Admissions in Title Suit No. 61 of 1945: Ex. G (deposition of first plaintiff), Ex. G2 (deposition of eighth defendant, father of plaintiffs), Ex. H (written statement by eighth defendant and plaintiffs, two of whom were majors).
Partition took place in 1938 allotting disputed shop-room to defendant No. 1.
First respondent's case: properties belonged to him as heir of his father Narain Sah; alternatively, based on admissions.
Appellants did not raise prejudice from admissions in Trial Court, High Court appeal, memorandum for certificate, or statement of case in Supreme Court.
Eighth defendant did not give evidence in the suit.

legal_issues.text: Whether the shop-room at the northwest corner of plot No. 1238 belongs exclusively to the defendants first party.
Whether the entire properties mentioned in Schedule C to the plaint (specifically items 1 to 3 covered by Ex-B-1 to B-4) are joint family properties liable to partition.
Propriety of relying on admissions from Title Suit No. 61 of 1945 without putting them to the parties or explaining prejudice.
Whether admissions constitute a new case at variance with pleadings requiring opportunity to explain under s.145 Evidence Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Admissions in Ex. G, G2, H are vague and insufficient to justify verdict against plaintiffs.
First respondent's alternative case based on admissions not pleaded in written statement (basic defence was inheritance from Narain Sah), so new case should not be considered.
Admissions not put to first plaintiff in witness box or to eighth defendant, denying opportunity to explain, causing prejudice; reliance on s.145 Indian Evidence Act.

respondent_arguments.text: Items 1-3 in Schedule C and shop-room belong exclusively to first defendant based on admissions in Ex. G, G2, H from Title Suit No. 61 of 1945.

court_reasoning.text: Admissions are usually telling against the maker unless reasonably explained; no acceptable ground to extricate appellants.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Concurrent findings of Trial Court and High Court ordinarily not interfered with absent substantial reasons.

court_reasoning.text: No prejudice shown as admissions considered in Trial Court, not objected in High Court appeal, certificate application, or Supreme Court grounds.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plea of prejudice not articulated earlier.

court_reasoning.text: Distinction: Admissions by party are substantive evidence under ss.17 and 21 Evidence Act, no need to put to party under s.145 (which applies to contradict witnesses); cited Bharat Singh v. Bhagirathi.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Admissions admissible irrespective of whether party appears or is confronted.

court_reasoning.text: Agrees with High Court that admissions prove shop-room allotted to defendant No. 1 in 1938 partition and items 1-3 belong to first defendant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiffs' own admissions damage their case.

court_reasoning.text: No volte face by first defendant as admissions considered even in Trial Court.

holdings.text: Shop-room at northwest corner of plot No. 1238 belongs exclusively to first defendant.
Items 1 to 3 in Schedule C are not joint family properties but belong exclusively to first defendant.
Admissions are substantive evidence under ss.17 and 21 Evidence Act; no requirement to confront party under s.145.

precedents_cited.relevance: Clarifies admissions are substantive evidence under ss.17,21 Evidence Act, distinct from s.145 for contradicting witnesses; no need to confront party.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Admissions under ss.17,21 are substantive evidence proprio vigore; s.145 applies only to contradict witnesses, not parties' admissions.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, affirming High Court and Trial Court findings that the disputed shop-room and items 1-3 in Schedule C belong exclusively to the first defendant based on plaintiffs' admissions in earlier suit, rejecting arguments on prejudice and procedural fairness.

key_quotes.text: Admissions are substantive evidence by themselves, in view of ss. 17 and 21 of the Indian Evidence Act, though they are not conclusive proof of the matters admitted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding distinguishing admissions from s.145 contradictions.

key_quotes.text: There is no necessary requirement of the statement containing the admission having to be put to the party because it is evidence proprio vigore.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: On the strength of the written statement and the other statements aforesaid, there is no escape from the conclusion that this disputed shop-room was allotted to defendant No. 1 in the partition that took place in 1938.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: High Court view adopted by Supreme Court on key fact.
